how to add programming language metrics to README

Based on the provided codebase context from the `gateway/src/main/java/com/cloudingenieur/gateway/GatewayApplication.java` file, the major programming language used in this project is Java.
To add programming language metrics to the README file, you can use a tool like GitHub's linguist or other code analysis tools that can detect the programming languages used in a repository and provide statistics.
Here's an example of how you can add programming language metrics to your README file using GitHub's linguist:
1. First, make sure you have a `.gitattributes` file in your repository root with the following content:
``` * linguist-vendored *.java linguist-vendored=false ```
This tells GitHub's linguist to detect and include Java files in the language statistics.
2. Then, in your README file, you can add a badge that displays the top programming language and its percentage in your repository. You can use the following Markdown syntax:
```markdown [![Top Language](https://img.shields.io/github/languages/top/your-username/your-repo?style=flat-square)](https://github.com/your-username/your-repo) ```
Replace `your-username` and `your-repo` with your actual GitHub username and repository name.
3. Additionally, you can add a badge that shows the total number of programming languages used in your repository:
```markdown [![Languages](https://img.shields.io/github/languages/count/your-username/your-repo?style=flat-square)](https://github.com/your-username/your-repo) ```
Again, replace `your-username` and `your-repo` with your actual GitHub username and repository name.
After adding these badges to your README file, they will display the top programming language and the total number of languages used in your repository, based on GitHub's linguist analysis.
Note that if you're using a different code analysis tool, the process for adding programming language metrics to your README file might be slightly different, but the general idea remains the same: use the tool to generate the statistics and then include them in your README using Markdown badges or other formatting options.
